statement: Prove that there are infinitely many natural numbers a such that n⁴ + a is never prime for any natural number n.
Let a₁,...,aₙ be real constants and f(x)=cos(a₁+x)+½cos(a₂+x)+⋯+(1/2ⁿ⁻¹)cos(aₙ+x). If f(x₁)=f(x₂)=0, prove x₂−x₁=mπ for some integer m.
For k=1,2,3,4,5 give necessary and sufficient conditions on a>0 so that a tetrahedron exists with k edges of length a and the remaining 6−k edges of length 1.
Semicircle γ on diameter AB, point C on γ, D foot of perpendicular from C to AB. γ₁ is incircle of △ABC; γ₂, γ₃ touch CD and γ, one on each side of CD. Prove γ₁, γ₂, γ₃ share a second common tangent.
Given n>4 points in the plane, no three collinear, prove there are at least C(n−3,2) convex quadrilaterals whose vertices are four of the given points.
For real x₁,x₂,y₁,y₂,z₁,z₂ with x₁,x₂>0 and xᵢyᵢ−zᵢ²>0, prove 8/[(x₁+x₂)(y₁+y₂)−(z₁+z₂)²] ≤ 1/(x₁y₁−z₁²) + 1/(x₂y₂−z₂²) and give conditions for equality.
